thread.title: Fears Debbie could wipe out Bowen
thread.title_full: Fears Debbie could wipe out Bowen

title: Fears Debbie could wipe out Bowen
text:
Queensland Cyclone: Everything you need to know 
AUTHORITIES are concerned Cyclone Debbie may completely flatten several parts of Bowen when it makes landfall Tuesday morning. 
​​Bowen hasn’t faced a major cyclone since Cyclone Connie in 1959, which means many houses were built before the 1980s and don’t meet cyclone standards. 
Experts believe many houses and beach huts around the Bowen region are vulnerable to being destroyed with powerful wind gusts of 240km/hr possible at the core of the cyclone. 
Whitsunday Mayor Andrew Willcox said every precaution was being taken to safeguard the town. media_camera The Bureau of Meteorology’s Cyclone Debbie tracking map, released at 1.58pm Monday. 
“Everyone’s pretty laid back in these coastal communities so we’re trying to get them fired up to take this cyclone seriously,” he said. 
“A lot of people are taping and boarding up their property. It’s been a few years since the last major cyclone hit Bowen directly. I’m hoping this one doesn’t (wipe the town off the map).” 
JCU Cyclone Testing Station research director Professor John Ginger said buildings in smaller coastal communities were vulnerable to being damaged. AU QLD: Wild Weather Hits Hamilton Island as Cyclone Debbie Nears March 27 0:20 
Those looking forward to a tropical, sunlit island holiday on Queensland?s north coast were left disappointed as storm conditions lashed the region amid warnings that a category three cyclone was approaching. Cyclone Debbie was upgraded to a level three and was expected to reach category four by the time it hit towns that included Mackay and Townsville, as well as the tourist hotspot of Hamilton Island. According to the Cairns Post, thousands were ordered to evacuate the northern coastline on Sunday, March 26, following warnings the cyclone would bring winds of more than 280km per hour. At about midday on Monday, additional, low-lying communities were ordered to evacuate, including Alva Beach and Groper Creek. Credit: Instagram/Rachael Aracic via Storyful March 27th 2017 /video/video.news.com.au/News/ AU QLD: Wild Weather Hits Hamilton Island as Cyclone Debbie Nears March 27 
“Houses built in the cyclonic regions of Queensland to improved building standards since the mid-1980s can be expected to withstand wind-loads forecast in TC Debbie (but) some older houses will be vulnerable to damage,” he said. 
“In 1989, (Category 3) Cyclone Aivu made landfall near Ayr/Home Hill and caused damage in the surrounding areas including Bowen. Houses in low-lying coastal regions especially to the south of the crossing, and are subjected to storm surge, will be vulnerable to significant damage.” media_camera Boarding up the Grand View Hotel, made famouse in the movie Australia , in Bowen. Picture: Lyndon Mechielsen 
Local farmers are also bracing for the worst with intense wind and rain expected to wreak havoc on their crops. 
Queensland Farmers Federation president Stuart Armitage said flooding could still impact farmers further inland from the coast. Cyclone Debbie upgraded to category three 2:00 
The Bureau of Meteorology has upgraded Cyclone Debbie to a category three system. March 27th 2017 /video/video.news.com.au/News/ Cyclone Debbie upgraded to category three 
“Winds (from Cyclone Debbie) will lead to widespread crop damage as well as significant damage to farm infrastructure for other intensive industries such as nurseries and chickens. 
“Farmers are bracing for the damaging winds and storm surges up and down the coast. The significant rain from the cyclone can also result in localised and extensive flooding. As the cyclone tracks south and inland farmers well outside the initial landfall region will be at risk of flooding.”
